articles.author: Reuters Editorial
articles.title: Senate vote on new Russia sanctions unlikely in September: McConnell
articles.description: Legislation warning Russia that it would face heavy U.S. sanctions if it is found interfering in November's congressional elections will not be voted on anytime soon, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell said on Tuesday as he also cited his strong interest …

articles.author: Reuters Editorial
articles.title: Russia denies Microsoft allegations it targeted U.S. think tanks: Ifax
articles.description: The Russian authorities deny allegations from Microsoft that hackers linked to Russia's government tried to target the websites of two right-wing U.S. think-tanks, the Interfax news agency reported on Tuesday.

articles.author: Brendan O'Brien
articles.title: Russian hacking of conservative groups sites thwarted: Microsoft
articles.description: Microsoft Corp said on Monday that it had recently thwarted hackers associated with Russian government attempting to steal user information from conservative groups that promote democracy and advocate for cybersecurity.

articles.author: Reuters Editorial
articles.title: Kremlin says it does not understand Microsoft's U.S. hacking allegations
articles.description: The Kremlin said on Tuesday it did not understand allegations from Microsoft that hackers linked to Russia's government had tried to target the websites of two right-wing U.S. think-tanks.

articles.author: James Oliphant
articles.title: Trump to hit the road with rallies for Republican candidates
articles.description: U.S. President Donald Trump plans to campaign aggressively on behalf of Republican candidates in the coming six weeks, holding as many as eight rallies and 16 fundraisers before the end of September.

articles.author: Claire Milhench
articles.title: New sanctions leave Russia debt holders less sure of Trump's help
articles.description: Loading up on Russian sovereign bonds was a consensus trade for emerging market investors once Donald Trump won the White House, but the U.S. President's failure to defuse the threat of ever-tighter sanctions has unnerved even the most bullish funds.

articles.author: Gabriela Baczynska
articles.title: EU diplomats expect delay in Brexit deal beyond October target
articles.description: European Union leaders are likely to have to hold an emergency summit in November to consider any Brexit agreement struck with Britain, missing an informal deadline the previous month, diplomats in Brussels said.

articles.author: Rosie Perper
articles.title: The 10 most important things in the world right now
articles.description: Hello! Here's what's happening on Tuesday. 1. US President Donald Trump says there's "no timeframe" for the end to the US-China trade war. The second set of Trump's tariffs — this time on $16 billion worth of Chinese imports to the US — are set to go live on …

articles.author: Karma Allen
articles.title: Microsoft alleges new Russian attacks ahead of midterm elections
articles.description: Microsoft has thwarted newly attempted cyberattacks by Russian hackers targeting U.S. political campaigns before the midterm elections, the company alleged Monday.

articles.author: The Associated Press
articles.title: States move quickly to tap into money for election security
articles.description: States are tapping into $380 million approved by Congress to help them shore up their election systems amid ongoing threats of Russian interference

articles.author: ABC News
articles.title: WATCH: SPECIAL REPORT: Trump's former attorney reaches plea deal including jail time
articles.description: Michael Cohen reached a deal with prosecutors on charges that include campaign finance violations, bank fraud and tax evasion.

articles.author: USA TODAY, John Fritze, USA TODAY
articles.title: President Trump plans to step up midterm travel, outpace Obama
articles.description: Trump will spend more than 40 days on the campaign trail ahead of the midterm elections, aiming to dedicate more time than Barack Obama did in 2010.

articles.author: USA TODAY, USA TODAY
articles.title: Paul Manafort trial, Alaska primaries, 3D-printed gun plans: 5 things to know Tuesday
articles.description: Paul Manafort jury deliberations, Alaska primaries and more things to start your day.

articles.author: smurray@politico.com (Stephanie Murray)
articles.title: Trump warns 'blue wave' would bring 'crime and open borders'
articles.description: Trump has long predicted that November's midterms will deliver a "red wave" of Republican victories, shielding or perhaps bolstering GOP majorities in both houses of Congress.

articles.author: River O'Connor
articles.title: I Just Hacked a State Election. I’m 17. And I’m Not Even a Very Good Hacker.
articles.description: It took a lot less than you'd think for myself and my fellow teens to steal the midterms.

articles.author: egeller@politico.com (Eric Geller)
articles.title: Microsoft: U.S. political system facing 'broadening cyberthreats' from Russia
articles.description: "In the face of this continuing activity," Microsoft said, "we must work on the assumption that these attacks will broaden further."

articles.author: Burgess Everett
articles.title: Sentencing reform tests Cotton’s sway with Trump
articles.description: Some of the president's staunchest allies are on opposite sides of the issue.

articles.author: eokun@politico.com (Eli Okun)
articles.title: POLITICO Playbook PM: Manafort jury asks judge about deadlock on one count, as NBC reports Michael Cohen might cut plea deal
articles.description: And Trump proposes to roll back Obama’s biggest climate rule.

articles.author: Isobel Asher Hamilton
articles.title: Facebook apologizes to right-wing group PragerU after being accused of censoring its videos
articles.description: Facebook apologized to a right-wing non-profit group after it blocked some of its videos, making them invisible to its followers. Facebook said the removal of the videos was a mistake, and they have been restored. PragerU seems unconvinced, claiming the remov…

articles.author: Lisa Barrington
articles.title: Lebanese chafe as economic blues begin to bite
articles.description: For Mazen Rahhal, a shopowner in a bustling district of Beirut, Lebanon's economy has seldom felt more precarious. In one store, he sells clothes at a fraction of their previous price. Another, which he rented to a rival business, now lies empty.
